message.content: This question requires knowledge about the effects of light pollution on our ability to see celestial objects. As light pollution increases, it becomes harder to see stars in the night sky because the artificial light from cities and other sources obscures their visibility. Option (A) is incorrect because the question is specifically asking about something that becomes harder to see, not what is eliminated completely. Option (B) is incorrect because the moon's brightness is not affected by light pollution. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun is not visible in the night sky.

This question requires an understanding of light pollution and its effects on our ability to see celestial objects. Light pollution refers to the excessive artificial light that brightens the night sky and obscures our view of stars and other celestial objects. As light pollution increases, it becomes harder to see stars because the excess light drowns out their faint glow. Therefore, the correct answer is option (C). Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because light pollution does not affect our ability to see the sky, moon, or sun, respectively.

This question requires knowledge about the effects of light pollution on visibility. As light pollution increases, it will become harder to see stars in the sky. This is because the excess artificial light in the surroundings creates a bright glow in the atmosphere, which obstructs the view of stars. The other options are not affected by light pollution in the same way. The sky and moon can still be seen, although they may appear less clear or vibrant. The sun is not impacted by light pollution since its brightness far surpasses any artificial light sources.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the effects of light pollution on our ability to see celestial objects. As light pollution increases, it becomes harder to see stars in the night sky. This is because the artificial light from streetlights, buildings, and other sources creates a bright glow that obscures the faint light emitted by stars. Option (A) is incorrect because light pollution actually makes the sky appear brighter. Option (B) is incorrect because the moon is relatively bright and can still be seen even under light polluted conditions. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun is the brightest object in the sky and can still be seen, even during daylight hours when light pollution is less noticeable.

This is because the excessive artificial light from streetlights, buildings, and other sources washes out the faint light emitted by distant stars. Option (A) is incorrect because the sky itself is still visible, just with less visible stars. Option (B) is incorrect because the moon is a bright celestial object and is not significantly affected by light pollution. Option (D) is incorrect because the sun is visible during the day and is not affected by light pollution at night.
